15. Computing Square Roots

15.1Introduction¶

Chapter 24 of Russell (2004) about early Greek mathematics and astronomy contains this fascinating passage:

This lecture drills down and studies this ancient method for computing square roots by using some of the matrix algebra that we’ve learned in earlier quantecon lectures.

In particular, this lecture can be viewed as a sequel to Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors.

It provides an example of how eigenvectors isolate invariant subspaces that help construct and analyze solutions of linear difference equations.

When vector xtx_txt​ starts in an invariant subspace, iterating the different equation keeps xt+jx_{t+j}xt+j​ in that subspace for all j≥1j \geq 1j≥1.

Invariant subspace methods are used throughout applied economic dynamics, for example, in the lecture Money Financed Government Deficits and Price Levels.

Our approach here is to illustrate the method with an ancient example, one that ancient Greek mathematicians used to compute square roots of positive integers.

15.2Perfect squares and irrational numbers¶

An integer is called a perfect square if its square root is also an integer.

An ordered sequence of perfect squares starts with

4,9,16,25,36,49,64,81,100,121,144,169,196,225,…4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81, 100, 121, 144, 169, 196, 225, \ldots4,9,16,25,36,49,64,81,100,121,144,169,196,225,…
(1)

If an integer is not a perfect square, then its square root is an irrational number -- i.e., it cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers, and its decimal expansion is indefinite.

The ancient Greeks invented an algorithm to compute square roots of integers, including integers that are not perfect squares.

Their method involved

  • computing a particular sequence of integers {yt}t=0∞\{y_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{yt​}t=0∞​;

  • computing lim⁡t→∞(yt+1yt)=rˉ\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{y_{t+1}}{y_t}\right) = \bar rlimt→∞​(yt​yt+1​​)=rˉ;

  • deducing the desired square root from rˉ\bar rrˉ.

In this lecture, we’ll describe this method.

We’ll also use invariant subspaces to describe variations on this method that are faster.

15.3Second-order linear difference equations¶

Before telling how the ancient Greeks computed square roots, we’ll provide a quick introduction to second-order linear difference equations.

We’ll study the following second-order linear difference equation

yt=a1yt−1+a2yt−2,t≥0y_t = a_1 y_{t-1} + a_2 y_{t-2}, \quad t \geq 0yt​=a1​yt−1​+a2​yt−2​,t≥0
(2)

where (y−1,y−2)(y_{-1}, y_{-2})(y−1​,y−2​) is a pair of given initial conditions.

Equation (2) is actually an infinite number of linear equations in the sequence {yt}t=0∞\{y_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{yt​}t=0∞​.

There is one equation each for t=0,1,2,…t = 0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,….

We could follow an approach taken in the lecture on present values and stack all of these equations into a single matrix equation that we would then solve by using matrix inversion.

Note

In the present instance, the matrix equation would multiply a countably infinite dimensional square matrix by a countably infinite dimensional vector. With some qualifications, matrix multiplication and inversion tools apply to such an equation.

But we won’t pursue that approach here.

Instead, we’ll seek to find a time-invariant function that solves our difference equation, meaning that it provides a formula for a {yt}t=0∞\{y_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{yt​}t=0∞​ sequence that satisfies equation (2) for each t≥0t \geq 0t≥0.

We seek an expression for yt,t≥0y_t, t \geq 0yt​,t≥0 as functions of the initial conditions (y−1,y−2)(y_{-1}, y_{-2})(y−1​,y−2​):

yt=g((y−1,y−2);t),t≥0.y_t = g((y_{-1}, y_{-2});t), \quad t \geq 0.yt​=g((y−1​,y−2​);t),t≥0.
(3)

We call such a function ggg a solution of the difference equation (2).

One way to discover a solution is to use a guess and verify method.

We shall begin by considering a special initial pair of initial conditions that satisfy

y−1=δy−2y_{-1} = \delta y_{-2}y−1​=δy−2​
(4)

where δ\deltaδ is a scalar to be determined.

For initial condition that satisfy (4) equation (2) impllies that

y0=(a1+a2δ)y−1.y_0 = \left(a_1 + \frac{a_2}{\delta}\right) y_{-1}.y0​=(a1​+δa2​​)y−1​.
(5)

We want

(a1+a2δ)=δ\left(a_1 + \frac{a_2}{\delta}\right) = \delta(a1​+δa2​​)=δ
(6)

which we can rewrite as the characteristic equation

δ2−a1δ−a2=0.\delta^2 - a_1 \delta - a_2 = 0.δ2−a1​δ−a2​=0.
(7)

Applying the quadratic formula to solve for the roots of (7) we find that

δ=a1±a12+4a22.\delta = \frac{ a_1 \pm \sqrt{a_1^2 + 4 a_2}}{2}.δ=2a1​±a12​+4a2​​​.
(8)

For either of the two δ\deltaδ’s that satisfy equation (8), a solution of difference equation (2) is

yt=δty0,∀t≥0y_t = \delta^t y_0 , \forall t \geq 0yt​=δty0​,∀t≥0
(9)

provided that we set

y0=δy−1.y_0 = \delta y_{-1} .y0​=δy−1​.
(10)

The general solution of difference equation (2) takes the form

yt=η1δ1t+η2δ2ty_t = \eta_1 \delta_1^t + \eta_2 \delta_2^tyt​=η1​δ1t​+η2​δ2t​
(11)

where δ1,δ2\delta_1, \delta_2δ1​,δ2​ are the two solutions (8) of the characteristic equation (7), and η1,η2\eta_1, \eta_2η1​,η2​ are two constants chosen to satisfy

[y−1y−2]=[δ1−1δ2−1δ1−2δ2−2][η1η2]\begin{bmatrix} y_{-1} \cr y_{-2} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \delta_1^{-1} & \delta_2^{-1} \cr \delta_1^{-2} & \delta_2^{-2} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \eta_1 \cr \eta_2 \end{bmatrix}[y−1​y−2​​]=[δ1−1​δ1−2​​δ2−1​δ2−2​​][η1​η2​​]
(12)

or

[η1η2]=[δ1−1δ2−1δ1−2δ2−2]−1[y−1y−2]\begin{bmatrix} \eta_1 \cr \eta_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \delta_1^{-1} & \delta_2^{-1} \cr \delta_1^{-2} & \delta_2^{-2} \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \begin{bmatrix} y_{-1} \cr y_{-2} \end{bmatrix}[η1​η2​​]=[δ1−1​δ1−2​​δ2−1​δ2−2​​]−1[y−1​y−2​​]
(13)

Sometimes we are free to choose the initial conditions (y−1,y−2)(y_{-1}, y_{-2})(y−1​,y−2​), in which case we use system (12) to find the associated (η1,η2)(\eta_1, \eta_2)(η1​,η2​).

If we choose (y−1,y−2)(y_{-1}, y_{-2})(y−1​,y−2​) to set (η1,η2)=(1,0)(\eta_1, \eta_2) = (1, 0)(η1​,η2​)=(1,0), then yt=δ1ty_t = \delta_1^tyt​=δ1t​ for all t≥0t \geq 0t≥0.

If we choose (y−1,y−2)(y_{-1}, y_{-2})(y−1​,y−2​) to set (η1,η2)=(0,1)(\eta_1, \eta_2) = (0, 1)(η1​,η2​)=(0,1), then yt=δ2ty_t = \delta_2^tyt​=δ2t​ for all t≥0t \geq 0t≥0.

Soon we’ll relate the preceding calculations to components an eigen decomposition of a transition matrix that represents difference equation (2) in a very convenient way.

We’ll turn to that after we describe how Ancient Greeks figured out how to compute square roots of positive integers that are not perfect squares.

15.4Algorithm of the Ancient Greeks¶

Let σ\sigmaσ be a positive integer greater than 1.

So σ∈I≡{2,3,…}\sigma \in {\mathcal I} \equiv \{2, 3, \ldots \}σ∈I≡{2,3,…}.

We want an algorithm to compute the square root of σ∈I\sigma \in {\mathcal I}σ∈I.

If σ∈I\sqrt{\sigma} \in {\mathcal I}σ​∈I, σ\sigma σ is said to be a perfect square.

If σ∉I\sqrt{\sigma} \not\in {\mathcal I}σ​∈I, it turns out that it is irrational.

Ancient Greeks used a recursive algorithm to compute square roots of integers that are not perfect squares.

The algorithm iterates on a second-order linear difference equation in the sequence {yt}t=0∞\{y_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{yt​}t=0∞​:

yt=2yt−1−(1−σ)yt−2,t≥0y_{t} = 2 y_{t-1} - (1 - \sigma) y_{t-2}, \quad t \geq 0yt​=2yt−1​−(1−σ)yt−2​,t≥0
(14)

together with a pair of integers that are initial conditions for y−1,y−2y_{-1}, y_{-2}y−1​,y−2​.

First, we’ll deploy some techniques for solving the difference equations that are also deployed in .

The characteristic equation associated with difference equation (14) is

c(x)≡x2−2x+(1−σ)=0c(x) \equiv x^2 - 2 x + (1 - \sigma) = 0c(x)≡x2−2x+(1−σ)=0
(15)

(Notice how this is an instance of equation (7) above.)

Factoring the right side of equation (15), we obtain

c(x)=(x−λ1)(x−λ2)=0c(x)= (x - \lambda_1) (x-\lambda_2) = 0c(x)=(x−λ1​)(x−λ2​)=0
(16)

where

c(x)=0c(x) = 0c(x)=0
(17)

for x=λ1x = \lambda_1x=λ1​ or x=λ2x = \lambda_2x=λ2​.

These two special values of xxx are sometimes called zeros or roots of c(x)c(x)c(x).

By applying the quadratic formula to solve for the roots the characteristic equation (15), we find that

λ1=1+σ,λ2=1−σ.\lambda_1 = 1 + \sqrt{\sigma}, \quad \lambda_2 = 1 - \sqrt{\sigma}.λ1​=1+σ​,λ2​=1−σ​.
(18)

Formulas (18) indicate that λ1\lambda_1λ1​ and λ2\lambda_2λ2​ are each functions of a single variable, namely, σ\sqrt{\sigma}σ​, the object that we along with some Ancient Greeks want to compute.

Ancient Greeks had an indirect way of exploiting this fact to compute square roots of a positive integer.

They did this by starting from particular initial conditions y−1,y−2y_{-1}, y_{-2}y−1​,y−2​ and iterating on the difference equation (14).

Solutions of difference equation (14) take the form

yt=λ1tη1+λ2tη2y_t = \lambda_1^t \eta_1 + \lambda_2^t \eta_2yt​=λ1t​η1​+λ2t​η2​
(19)

where η1\eta_1η1​ and η2\eta_2η2​ are chosen to satisfy prescribed initial conditions y−1,y−2y_{-1}, y_{-2}y−1​,y−2​:

λ1−1η1+λ2−1η2=y−1λ1−2η1+λ2−2η2=y−2\begin{aligned} \lambda_1^{-1} \eta_1 + \lambda_2^{-1} \eta_2 & = y_{-1} \cr \lambda_1^{-2} \eta_1 + \lambda_2^{-2} \eta_2 & = y_{-2} \end{aligned}λ1−1​η1​+λ2−1​η2​λ1−2​η1​+λ2−2​η2​​=y−1​=y−2​​
(20)

System (20) of simultaneous linear equations will play a big role in the remainder of this lecture.

Since λ1=1+σ>1>λ2=1−σ\lambda_1 = 1 + \sqrt{\sigma} > 1 > \lambda_2 = 1 - \sqrt{\sigma} λ1​=1+σ​>1>λ2​=1−σ​, it follows that for almost all (but not all) initial conditions

lim⁡t→∞(yt+1yt)=1+σ.\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{y_{t+1}}{y_t}\right) = 1 + \sqrt{\sigma}.t→∞lim​(yt​yt+1​​)=1+σ​.
(21)

Thus,

σ=lim⁡t→∞(yt+1yt)−1.\sqrt{\sigma} = \lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{y_{t+1}}{y_t}\right) - 1.σ​=t→∞lim​(yt​yt+1​​)−1.
(22)

However, notice that if η1=0\eta_1 = 0η1​=0, then

lim⁡t→∞(yt+1yt)=1−σ\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{y_{t+1}}{y_t}\right) = 1 - \sqrt{\sigma}t→∞lim​(yt​yt+1​​)=1−σ​
(23)

so that

σ=1−lim⁡t→∞(yt+1yt).\sqrt{\sigma} = 1 - \lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{y_{t+1}}{y_t}\right).σ​=1−t→∞lim​(yt​yt+1​​).
(24)

Actually, if η1=0\eta_1 =0η1​=0, it follows that

σ=1−(yt+1yt)∀t≥0,\sqrt{\sigma} = 1 - \left(\frac{y_{t+1}}{y_t}\right) \quad \forall t \geq 0,σ​=1−(yt​yt+1​​)∀t≥0,
(25)

so that convergence is immediate and there is no need to take limits.

Symmetrically, if η2=0\eta_2 =0η2​=0, it follows that

σ=(yt+1yt)−1∀t≥0\sqrt{\sigma} = \left(\frac{y_{t+1}}{y_t}\right) - 1 \quad \forall t \geq 0σ​=(yt​yt+1​​)−1∀t≥0
(26)

so again, convergence is immediate, and we have no need to compute a limit.

System (20) of simultaneous linear equations can be used in various ways.

  • we can take y−1,y−2y_{-1}, y_{-2}y−1​,y−2​ as given initial conditions and solve for η1,η2\eta_1, \eta_2η1​,η2​;

  • we can instead take η1,η2\eta_1, \eta_2η1​,η2​ as given and solve for initial conditions y−1,y−2y_{-1}, y_{-2}y−1​,y−2​.

Notice how we used the second approach above when we set η1,η2\eta_1, \eta_2η1​,η2​ either to (0,1)(0, 1)(0,1), for example, or (1,0)(1, 0)(1,0), for example.

In taking this second approach, we constructed an invariant subspace of R2{\bf R}^2R2.

Here is what is going on.

For t≥0 t \geq 0t≥0 and for most pairs of initial conditions (y−1,y−2)∈R2(y_{-1}, y_{-2}) \in {\bf R}^2(y−1​,y−2​)∈R2 for equation (14), yty_tyt​ can be expressed as a linear combination of yt−1y_{t-1}yt−1​ and yt−2y_{t-2}yt−2​.

But for some special initial conditions (y−1,y−2)∈R2(y_{-1}, y_{-2}) \in {\bf R}^2(y−1​,y−2​)∈R2, yty_tyt​ can be expressed as a linear function of yt−1y_{t-1}yt−1​ only.

These special initial conditions require that y−1y_{-1}y−1​ be a linear function of y−2y_{-2}y−2​.

We’ll study these special initial conditions soon.

But first let’s write some Python code to iterate on equation (14) starting from an arbitrary (y−1,y−2)∈R2(y_{-1}, y_{-2}) \in {\bf R}^2(y−1​,y−2​)∈R2.

15.5Implementation¶

We now implement the above algorithm to compute the square root of σ\sigmaσ.

In this lecture, we use the following import:

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
def solve_λs(coefs):    
    # Calculate the roots using numpy.roots
    λs = np.roots(coefs)
    
    # Sort the roots for consistency
    return sorted(λs, reverse=True)

def solve_η(λ_1, λ_2, y_neg1, y_neg2):
    # Solve the system of linear equation
    A = np.array([
        [1/λ_1, 1/λ_2],
        [1/(λ_1**2), 1/(λ_2**2)]
    ])
    b = np.array((y_neg1, y_neg2))
    ηs = np.linalg.solve(A, b)
    
    return ηs

def solve_sqrt(σ, coefs, y_neg1, y_neg2, t_max=100):
    # Ensure σ is greater than 1
    if σ <= 1:
        raise ValueError("σ must be greater than 1")
        
    # Characteristic roots
    λ_1, λ_2 = solve_λs(coefs)
    
    # Solve for η_1 and η_2
    η_1, η_2 = solve_η(λ_1, λ_2, y_neg1, y_neg2)

    # Compute the sequence up to t_max
    t = np.arange(t_max + 1)
    y = (λ_1 ** t) * η_1 + (λ_2 ** t) * η_2
    
    # Compute the ratio y_{t+1} / y_t for large t
    sqrt_σ_estimate = (y[-1] / y[-2]) - 1
    
    return sqrt_σ_estimate

# Use σ = 2 as an example
σ = 2

# Encode characteristic equation
coefs = (1, -2, (1 - σ))

# Solve for the square root of σ
sqrt_σ = solve_sqrt(σ, coefs, y_neg1=2, y_neg2=1)

# Calculate the deviation
dev = abs(sqrt_σ-np.sqrt(σ))
print(f"sqrt({σ}) is approximately {sqrt_σ:.5f} (error: {dev:.5f})")

Now we consider cases where (η1,η2)=(0,1)(\eta_1, \eta_2) = (0, 1)(η1​,η2​)=(0,1) and (η1,η2)=(1,0)(\eta_1, \eta_2) = (1, 0)(η1​,η2​)=(1,0)

# Compute λ_1, λ_2
λ_1, λ_2 = solve_λs(coefs)
print(f'Roots for the characteristic equation are ({λ_1:.5f}, {λ_2:.5f}))')
# Case 1: η_1, η_2 = (0, 1)
ηs = (0, 1)

# Compute y_{t} and y_{t-1} with t >= 0
y = lambda t, ηs: (λ_1 ** t) * ηs[0] + (λ_2 ** t) * ηs[1]
sqrt_σ = 1 - y(1, ηs) / y(0, ηs)

print(f"For η_1, η_2 = (0, 1), sqrt_σ = {sqrt_σ:.5f}")
# Case 2: η_1, η_2 = (1, 0)
ηs = (1, 0)
sqrt_σ = y(1, ηs) / y(0, ηs) - 1

print(f"For η_1, η_2 = (1, 0), sqrt_σ = {sqrt_σ:.5f}")

We find that convergence is immediate.

Next, we’ll represent the preceding analysis by first vectorizing our second-order difference equation (14) and then using eigendecompositions of an associated state transition matrix.

15.6Vectorizing the difference equation¶

Represent (14) with the first-order matrix difference equation

[yt+1yt]=[2−(1−σ)10][ytyt−1]\begin{bmatrix} y_{t+1} \cr y_{t} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & - ( 1 - \sigma) \cr 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} y_{t} \cr y_{t-1} \end{bmatrix}[yt+1​yt​​]=[21​−(1−σ)0​][yt​yt−1​​]
(27)

or

xt+1=Mxtx_{t+1} = M x_txt+1​=Mxt​
(28)

where

M=[2−(1−σ)10],xt=[ytyt−1]M = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & - (1 - \sigma ) \cr 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad x_t= \begin{bmatrix} y_{t} \cr y_{t-1} \end{bmatrix}M=[21​−(1−σ)0​],xt​=[yt​yt−1​​]
(29)

Construct an eigendecomposition of MMM:

M=V[λ100λ2]V−1M = V \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 \cr 0 & \lambda_2 \end{bmatrix} V^{-1}M=V[λ1​0​0λ2​​]V−1
(30)

where columns of VVV are eigenvectors corresponding to eigenvalues λ1\lambda_1λ1​ and λ2\lambda_2λ2​.

The eigenvalues can be ordered so that λ1>1>λ2\lambda_1 > 1 > \lambda_2λ1​>1>λ2​.

Write equation (14) as

xt+1=VΛV−1xtx_{t+1} = V \Lambda V^{-1} x_txt+1​=VΛV−1xt​
(31)

Now we implement the algorithm above.

First we write a function that iterates MMM

def iterate_M(x_0, M, num_steps, dtype=np.float64):
    
    # Eigendecomposition of M
    Λ, V = np.linalg.eig(M)
    V_inv = np.linalg.inv(V)
    
    # Initialize the array to store results
    xs = np.zeros((x_0.shape[0], 
                   num_steps + 1))
    
    # Perform the iterations
    xs[:, 0] = x_0
    for t in range(num_steps):
        xs[:, t + 1] = M @ xs[:, t]
    
    return xs, Λ, V, V_inv

# Define the state transition matrix M
M = np.array([
      [2, -(1 - σ)],
      [1, 0]])

# Initial condition vector x_0
x_0 = np.array([2, 2])

# Perform the iteration
xs, Λ, V, V_inv = iterate_M(x_0, M, num_steps=100)

print(f"eigenvalues:\n{Λ}")
print(f"eigenvectors:\n{V}")
print(f"inverse eigenvectors:\n{V_inv}")

Let’s compare the eigenvalues to the roots (18) of equation (15) that we computed above.

roots = solve_λs((1, -2, (1 - σ)))
print(f"roots: {np.round(roots, 8)}")

Hence we confirmed (30).

Information about the square root we are after is also contained in the two eigenvectors.

Indeed, each eigenvector is just a two-dimensional subspace of R3{\mathbb R}^3R3 pinned down by dynamics of the form

yt=λiyt−1,i=1,2y_{t} = \lambda_i y_{t-1}, \quad i = 1, 2yt​=λi​yt−1​,i=1,2
(32)

that we encountered above in equation (9) above.

In equation (32), the iiith λi\lambda_iλi​ equals the Vi,1/Vi,2V_{i, 1}/V_{i,2}Vi,1​/Vi,2​.

The following graph verifies this for our example.

Source
# Plotting the eigenvectors
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 8))

           scale=1, color='C1', label=fr'$\lambda_2={np.round(Λ[1], 4)}$')

# Annotating the slopes
plt.text(V[0, 0]-0.5, V[1, 0]*1.2,

         fontsize=12, color='C0')
plt.text(V[0, 1]-0.5, V[1, 1]*1.2,

         fontsize=12, color='C1')

plt.axhline(0, color='grey', linewidth=0.5, alpha=0.4)
plt.axvline(0, color='grey', linewidth=0.5, alpha=0.4)
plt.legend()

plt.xlim(-1.5, 1.5)
plt.ylim(-1.5, 1.5)
plt.show()

15.7Invariant subspace approach¶

The preceding calculation indicates that we can use the eigenvectors VVV to construct 2-dimensional invariant subspaces.

We’ll pursue that possibility now.

Define the transformed variables

xt∗=V−1xtx_t^* = V^{-1} x_txt∗​=V−1xt​
(33)

Evidently, we can recover xtx_txt​ from xt∗x_t^*xt∗​:

xt=Vxt∗x_t = V x_t^*xt​=Vxt∗​
(34)

The following notations and equations will help us.

Let

$$

V = \begin{bmatrix} V_{1,1} & V_{1,2} \cr V_{2,1} & V_{2,2} \end{bmatrix}, \quad V^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} V^{1,1} & V^{1,2} \cr V^{2,1} & V^{2,2} \end{bmatrix} $$

Notice that it follows from

[V1,1V1,2V2,1V2,2][V1,1V1,2V2,1V2,2]=[1001]\begin{bmatrix} V^{1,1} & V^{1,2} \cr V^{2,1} & V^{2,2} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} V_{1,1} & V_{1,2} \cr V_{2,1} & V_{2,2} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \cr 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}[V1,1V2,1​V1,2V2,2​][V1,1​V2,1​​V1,2​V2,2​​]=[10​01​]
(35)

that

V2,1V1,1+V2,2V2,1=0V^{2,1} V_{1,1} + V^{2,2} V_{2,1} = 0V2,1V1,1​+V2,2V2,1​=0
(36)

and

V1,1V1,2+V1,2V2,2=0.V^{1,1}V_{1,2} + V^{1,2} V_{2,2} = 0.V1,1V1,2​+V1,2V2,2​=0.
(37)

These equations will be very useful soon.

Notice that

[x1,t+1∗x2,t+1∗]=[λ100λ2][x1,t∗x2,t∗]\begin{bmatrix} x_{1,t+1}^* \cr x_{2,t+1}^* \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 \cr 0 & \lambda_2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1,t}^* \cr x_{2,t}^* \end{bmatrix}[x1,t+1∗​x2,t+1∗​​]=[λ1​0​0λ2​​][x1,t∗​x2,t∗​​]
(38)

To deactivate λ1\lambda_1λ1​ we want to set

x1,0∗=0.x_{1,0}^* = 0.x1,0∗​=0.
(39)

This can be achieved by setting

x2,0=−(V1,2)−1V1,1x1,0=V2,2V1,2−1x1,0.x_{2,0} = -( V^{1,2})^{-1} V^{1,1} x_{1,0} = V_{2,2} V_{1,2}^{-1} x_{1,0}.x2,0​=−(V1,2)−1V1,1x1,0​=V2,2​V1,2−1​x1,0​.
(40)

To deactivate λ2\lambda_2λ2​, we want to set

x2,0∗=0x_{2,0}^* = 0x2,0∗​=0
(41)

This can be achieved by setting

x2,0=−(V2,2)−1V2,1x1,0=V2,1V1,1−1x1,0.x_{2,0} = -(V^{2,2})^{-1} V^{2,1} x_{1,0} = V_{2,1} V_{1,1}^{-1} x_{1,0}.x2,0​=−(V2,2)−1V2,1x1,0​=V2,1​V1,1−1​x1,0​.
(42)

Let’s verify (40) and (42) below

To deactivate λ1\lambda_1λ1​ we use (40)

xd_1 = np.array((x_0[0], 
                 V[1,1]/V[0,1] * x_0[0]),
                dtype=np.float64)

# Compute x_{1,0}^*
np.round(V_inv @ xd_1, 8)

We find x1,0∗=0x_{1,0}^* = 0x1,0∗​=0.

Now we deactivate λ2\lambda_2λ2​ using (42)

xd_2 = np.array((x_0[0], 
                 V[1,0]/V[0,0] * x_0[0]), 
                 dtype=np.float64)

# Compute x_{2,0}^*
np.round(V_inv @ xd_2, 8)

We find x2,0∗=0x_{2,0}^* = 0x2,0∗​=0.

# Simulate with muted λ1 λ2.
num_steps = 10
xs_λ1 = iterate_M(xd_1, M, num_steps)[0]
xs_λ2 = iterate_M(xd_2, M, num_steps)[0]

15.8Concluding remarks¶

This lecture sets the stage for many other applications of the invariant subspace methods.

All of these exploit very similar equations based on eigen decompositions.

We shall encounter equations very similar to (40) and (42) in Money Financed Government Deficits and Price Levels and in many other places in dynamic economic theory.

15.9Exercise¶

Exercise 1

Please use matrix algebra to formulate the method described by Bertrand Russell at the beginning of this lecture.

  1. Define a state vector xt=[atbt]x_t = \begin{bmatrix} a_t \cr b_t \end{bmatrix}xt​=[at​bt​​].

  2. Formulate a first-order vector difference equation for xtx_txt​ of the form xt+1=Axtx_{t+1} = A x_txt+1​=Axt​ and compute the matrix AAA.

  3. Use the system xt+1=Axtx_{t+1} = A x_txt+1​=Axt​ to replicate the sequence of ata_tat​’s and btb_tbt​’s described by Bertrand Russell.

  4. Compute the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of AAA and compare them to corresponding objects computed in the text of this lecture.

Solution to Exercise 1

Here is one soluition.

According to the quote, we can formulate

at+1=at+btbt+1=2at+bt\begin{aligned} a_{t+1} &= a_t + b_t \\ b_{t+1} &= 2a_t + b_t \end{aligned}at+1​bt+1​​=at​+bt​=2at​+bt​​
(43)

with x0=[a0b0]=[11]x_0 = \begin{bmatrix} a_0 \cr b_0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 1 \end{bmatrix}x0​=[a0​b0​​]=[11​]

By (43), we can write matrix AAA as

A=[1121]A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \cr 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}A=[12​11​]
(44)

Then xt+1=Axtx_{t+1} = A x_txt+1​=Axt​ for t∈{0,…,5}t \in \{0, \dots, 5\}t∈{0,…,5}

# Define the matrix A
A = np.array([[1, 1],
              [2, 1]])

# Initial vector x_0
x_0 = np.array([1, 1])

# Number of iterations
n = 6

# Generate the sequence
xs = np.array([x_0])
x_t = x_0
for _ in range(1, n):
    x_t = A @ x_t
    xs = np.vstack([xs, x_t])

# Print the sequence
for i, (a_t, b_t) in enumerate(xs):
    print(f"Iter {i}: a_t = {a_t}, b_t = {b_t}")

# Compute eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A
eigenvalues, eigenvectors = np.linalg.eig(A)

print(f'\nEigenvalues:\n{eigenvalues}')
print(f'\nEigenvectors:\n{eigenvectors}')
